raw_text:
Consumer spending lifts US growth
 
 US economic growth accelerated in the third quarter, helped by strong consumer spending, official figures have shown.
 
 The economy expanded at an annual rate of 3.7% in the July to September period, the Commerce Department said. The figure marked an increase on the 3.3% growth recorded in the second quarter, but fell short of the 4.2% rate pencilled in by forecasters. The increase reflected the biggest jump in consumer spending in a year. "It was a little softer than the consensus, but not a real surprise," said Gary Thayer, an economist at AG Edwards & Sons. Friday's growth estimate is one of the last significant pieces of economic data before the 2 November presidential election.
 
 Democrat challenger John Kerry has criticised President George W Bush's handling of the economy, pointing to a net loss of over 800,000 jobs since Mr Bush took office. Analysts said the economy was still not growing fast enough to stimulate large-scale job creation. "It's a pretty good growth rate, but it may not be good enough to create enough jobs," said Robert Brusca, chief economist at Fact and Opinion Economics in New York. However, President Bush is expected to point to Commerce Department figures showing that consumer spending grew at 4.6% in the third quarter, up from just 1.6% in the second, as evidence that his policies are generating solid growth. Consumer spending accounts for about two thirds of all economic activity in the US.
 
 The weaker than expected growth figure makes it less likely that the US Federal Reserve will raise interest rates next month, economists said. "The economy regained some traction in the third quarter, but the growth is not robust," AG Edwards' Thayer. "I think that means the Fed can take its time raising rates. We'll probably see one more rate hike before the end of the year." In an effort to pre-empt rising inflation, the Federal Reserve has pushed through three quarter-point rate rises since June this year, taking borrowing costs to 1.75%. On the financial markets, the dollar fell slightly against the euro and the yen, while the Dow Jones index of leading US shares was little changed.
llama3.2:1b: US economic growth in the third quarter increased by 3.7% to 4.2%, but fell short of expectations due to a decline in consumer spending.
Consumer spending accounted for around two-thirds of all economic activity in the US, with a strong jump of 1.6%.
This was followed by slower job creation and weaker-than-expected growth figures, leading economists to expect the Federal Reserve to take its time raising interest rates next month.
llama3.2:3b: US economic growth accelerated in Q3 to 3.7%, driven by strong consumer spending, beating expectations but falling short of forecasters' 4.2%.
Consumer spending jumped 4.6% in Q3, up from 1.6% in Q2.
The stronger-than-expected figure makes it less likely the US Federal Reserve will raise interest rates next month.
gemma2:2b: US economic growth accelerated at an annual rate of 3.7% in the third quarter, boosted by strong consumer spending.
While this figure is above the second quarter's 3.3% but fell short of forecasts and analysts' expectations for stronger growth.
Consumer spending grew at a rate of 4.6% in the third quarter.
The weak economic growth may lead to no interest rate hike from the Federal Reserve next month.
The dollar weakened against the euro and yen while the Dow Jones index was little changed.
qwen2.5:0.5b: US economic growth accelerated in the third quarter due to strong consumer spending, as indicated by official figures from the Commerce Department.
Consumer spending accounted for approximately two-thirds of all economic activity in the US, which is about 46% of total output during the same period.
However, despite this, weaker than expected growth figures from the Federal Reserve mean that they may have to wait a bit longer before raising interest rates next month.
qwen2.5:1.5b: US economic growth accelerated in Q3 due to strong consumer spending, marking an annual rate of 3.7%, up from 3.3% but short of forecasts of 4.2%.
Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of economic activity.
President Bush's job creation efforts are expected to be bolstered by third-quarter figures showing 4.6% growth in consumer spending.
The Federal Reserve is likely to postpone interest rate hikes until the end of the year due to weaker-than-expected Q3 data.
qwen2.5:3b: US economic growth accelerated in the third quarter, driven by robust consumer spending, according to official figures.
The economy expanded at an annual rate of 3.7%, up from 3.3% in Q2 but below forecasters' expectation of 4.2%.
Consumer spending rose by 4.6% in Q3, up from 1.6% in Q2, a significant increase reflecting its role as two-thirds of US economic activity.
This growth was insufficient for substantial job creation and did not support the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates next month.
The dollar weakened against major currencies, and stock markets showed minimal change.
opencoder:1.5b: Consumer spending lifts US growth, accelerating economic growth and showing a clear growth in consumer spending accounts for about two thirds of all economic activity in the US.
The weaker than expected growth figure makes it less likely that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates next month.
The increase reflected the biggest jump in consumer spending in a year, but fell short of the 4.2% rate pencilled in by forecasters.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is:

"US economic growth lifted US growth in the third quarter, helped by strong consumer spending."

This summary captures the main idea of the original text, which is that the US economy grew at a rate of 3.7% in the third quarter, with strong consumer spending being one of the key drivers of this growth.
The text also mentions that the economy expanded at an annual rate of 4.2%, and that consumer spending was responsible for about two-thirds of all economic activity in the US.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Consumer spending contributed significantly to U.S. economic growth in the third quarter, driven by strong consumer spending.
The economy expanded at a annual rate of 3.7% from July to September, surpassing the previous year's 3.3%.
This growth was notable despite the Fed's forecast of 4.6% growth, showing that consumer Spending, which accounts for two-thirds of U.S. economic activity, is driving strong economic momentum.
John Kerry criticized President Bush on job losses, suggesting potential slowdowns in job creation.
The dollar weakened against major currencies like the euro and yen, with a slight rise in the Dow Jones index reflecting US market sentiment.
tinyllama:1.1b: The third quarter economic growth in the US accelerated at a slower pace compared to the previous two quarters, as consumer spendings rose by 4.6%, according to Commercé Department data.
Despite strong consumer spending, economic growth remained sluggish and is not expected to contribute to job creation sufficiently.
However, the weakened growth rate may be less significant than earlier predicted due to a net loss of over 800,000 jobs since President George W. Bush took office.
The Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates before the end of the year, pre-empting rising inflation, in an effort to prevent further economic downturns.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The summary text provided is as follows: Consumer spending growth accelerated in the third quarter, contributing to a faster-than-expected economic expansion.
Despite a slight decline from second-quarter levels, the US economy expanded at an annual rate of 3.7%, compared to the expected 4.2% for a July to September period.
This acceleration in consumer spending was attributed to strong gains across various sectors, with personal consumption expenditures rising by 5.3% on a year-over-year basis.
This positive outcome helped support robust job growth, as the economy added 800,000 jobs during this period.
The slowing of overall economic activity may have been attributed to lingering concerns over the state of the US economy, particularly with respect to employment and inflation.

However, President George W. Bush's administration has maintained a relatively stable stance on economic policies since his re-election in November 2004, suggesting that there is still a lot of room for growth and job creation within the framework of the current US government.
phi:2.7b: According to Commerce Department figures released today, US economic growth accelerated in the third quarter with consumer spending being a major contributor.
The economy expanded at an annual rate of 3.7% during this period, marked by a significant jump in consumer spending.
While this growth is stronger than the 2.3% recorded in the second quarter, it falls short of the 4.2% estimate made by economists.
However, President Bush has pointed out that this growth rate may be sufficient to create enough jobs.
Analysts believe that interest rates are unlikely to rise next month due to this weaker than expected growth figure.
This is because consumer spending accounts for about two thirds of all economic activity in the US.
The weaker than expected growth makes it less likely that the Federal Reserve will raise rates soon.

However, job creation remained slow, and the weaker-than-expected growth figure makes it less likely that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates next month.

However, some believe the economy's growth rate may not be fast enough to stimulate large-scale job creation.
President Bush's administration cites strong consumer spending as evidence of successful economic policies.
Economists predict the US Federal Reserve will continue to raise interest rates gradually, with one more hike expected before the end of the year, in an effort to prevent inflation.

The weaker-than-expected growth makes an imminent Federal Reserve interest rate hike less likely, though one more increase is expected before year-end.
The dollar fell slightly, while the Dow Jones remained stable.

To summarize: The US economy grew at a faster rate in Q3 (3.7%) due to strong consumer spending, but this growth is not enough to create many jobs and may not meet expectations.

President Bush will point to this data as evidence that his policies are generating solid growth; however, the Federal Reserve has been steadily raising interest rates to prevent an increase in inflation.
The dollar fell slightly against the euro and yen on financial markets, while the Dow Jones index remained unchanged.
granite3.1-dense:2b: US economic growth accelerated in Q3 to an annual rate of 3.7%, according to the Commerce Department, marking a 0.4% increase from the second quarter's 3.3%.
This growth was primarily driven by robust consumer spending, which saw its biggest yearly jump yet.
However, this figure fell short of forecasts' 4.2% projection and was slightly less than expected, making it less probable for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates next month.
President Bush highlighted the 4.6% increase in consumer spending from the second quarter, positioning these figures as evidence of his economic policies' effectiveness.
Analysts noted that while the growth rate is good, it may not be sufficient for substantial job creation.
Consumer spending constitutes about two-thirds of US economic activity.
Following this announcement, the dollar slightly weakened against the euro and yen, with the Dow Jones index remaining stable.
Democratic presidential candidate John Kerry criticized Bush's economic management, citing a net job loss of over 800,000 since his election.
